sen.j: 竹刀（しない）は、日本の武道である剣道の稽古および試合で防具 (剣道)に対して打突する竹でできた刀の代替品である。
sen.e: Shinai is substitute of sword made by bamboo, which is used in Japanese Traditional martial art, Kendo training, or being used to hit or push against protective armor in the Kendo tournament.
Shinai is a substitute sword made of bamboo used in the Japanese martial art of kendo for training or for hitting or pushing against armor in tournaments.

sen.j: 安土桃山時代に剣術の一部流派の打ち合い稽古のために袋竹刀が考案され、更に江戸時代になって防具の発達にともない割竹刀（わりじない）が考案された。
sen.e: The fukuro shinai (bamboo sword covered with a bag) was designed for hitting training of certain school of sword play in Azuchi momoyama period, furthermore, warijinai (split bamboo sword) was designed as the protective armor got improved in Edo period.

In the Azuchi-Momoyama Period (1558-1600), some kenjutsu, or sword fighting, schools began using bamboo swords covered with leather sleeves and called 'fukuro shinai' for sparring practice, and the Edo Period (1603-1868), with the development of armor, saw the appearance of the 'warijinai' (split bamboo sword).

sen.j: 元々は日本刀とほぼ同じ長さであったが、江戸時代末期に試合に有利なため4尺を超える竹刀を使用する者が多く現れ（5尺3寸≒161cmの長大な竹刀を使用した大石進が代表的である）、その対抗上、竹刀の長さは刀より長いものを使用するようになったといわれている。
sen.e: Originally it was the same length as Japanese sword, however many people started using long Shinai which was longer than 1.2 meters since it had advantage in the tournament (大石進 who used very long shinai of 5 shaku 3 zun (equivalent to 161 cm) is well known.), due to this tournament, it is said shinai longer than sword is started to be used in common.

Although originally the same length as Japanese swords,towards the end of the Edo period, many people started using shinai over 1.2 meters long since it gave them an advantage in tournaments (the famous Susumu OISHI used a very long shinai of 5 shaku 3 zun, or about 161 cm), and as people tried to out do each other, the longer shinai became common.
